body_html:
I assume ProcessPoolExecutor uses fork() internally, and forking after the TensorFlow runtime creates internal threads is unsafe. Fortunately, there are two workarounds:

  1. Use ThreadPoolExecutor instead of ProcessPoolExecutor.
  2. Use tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(use_per_session_threads=True)) instead of tf.Session().
body_text:
I assume ProcessPoolExecutor uses fork() internally, and forking after the TensorFlow runtime creates internal threads is unsafe. Fortunately, there are two workarounds:

Use ThreadPoolExecutor instead of ProcessPoolExecutor.
Use tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(use_per_session_threads=True)) instead of tf.Session().
body:
I assume `ProcessPoolExecutor` uses `fork()` internally, and forking after the TensorFlow runtime creates internal threads is unsafe. Fortunately, there are two workarounds:

1. Use `ThreadPoolExecutor` instead of `ProcessPoolExecutor`.
2. Use `tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(use_per_session_threads=True))` instead of `tf.Session()`.
